> To be frank, it sounds like Java's access protection mechanisms are
> insufficiently powerful.

I'm not sure they were meant for the things you are trying to use them for.

> Not your fault and not mine, but there's a
> pretty clear missing level. public-private-protected-default are
> insufficient. Too much gets marked as public that really shouldn't be.

Only if you think that public=published. Otherwise it's just fine to use it
a lot.

> Internal APIs need to be distinguished from published APIs, and Java
> doesn't let you do that across package boundaries. As I said, this may
> get better in the 1.6/1.7 time frame.

In fact I think the problem is even more complex. You might even want to
publish different things to different clients. It's probably something that
is better solved at a custom annotation level than on the basic language
level.

Cheers, Ilja
